Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to the next address, my van loaded with groceries. The order was marked “urgent”—the customer had called twice, asking if I could make it before six. Dinner plans, they’d said, and I could hear the worry in their voice. I knew how much people depended on these deliveries, especially on weekends. But as I checked the time again, my heart tightened. Sunday service at church was starting in twenty minutes, and I’d promised myself I’d go this week. I missed the singing, the prayers, the sense of belonging. My pastor always said, “Honor your commitments to God and your neighbor.” But what if those commitments pulled me in opposite directions? If I rushed the delivery, I might make it to church, but risk a mistake or a late drop-off. If I stayed to ensure the customer got their groceries on time, I’d miss worship—again. My hands gripped the steering wheel, torn between the ticking clock and the quiet call of faith, unsure which promise I should keep.
